importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, marking the announcement of Daniel Naroditsky's death.
The year Daniel Naroditsky won the Under 12 world championship, a pivotal moment in his early career.
The year he graduated with a bachelor's degree in history from Stanford University.
The date he completed his undergraduate studies at Stanford and took a year off to play in tournaments.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The span from Naroditsky's early success in 2007 to his death in 2025 reflects his long-standing influence in the chess world.

keyTakeAways: Daniel Naroditsky, a U.S. chess grandmaster, died at age 29, leaving behind a legacy as a prominent educator and communicator in the chess community.
He won the Under 12 world championship in 2007 and rose to become a top-ranked player in both traditional and blitz chess.
Naroditsky gained widespread popularity through livestreaming matches and educational commentary on platforms like YouTube and Twitch.
He was known for his passion for teaching and making chess accessible to a broader audience, especially younger fans.
He was a close friend and fellow grandmaster to Dutch player Benjamin Bok, and his death has deeply affected the global chess community.

Naroditsky was born in San Mateo County, California, to Ukrainian and Azerbaijani Jewish immigrant parents, and studied history at Stanford University before becoming a coach in Charlotte, North Carolina.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Daniel Naroditsky, a renowned American chess grandmaster and child prodigy, died at the age of 29. Born in San Mateo County, California, to Ukrainian and Azerbaijani Jewish immigrant parents, he rose to prominence by winning the Under 12 world championship in 2007 and becoming a grandmaster at 18. He gained global recognition through his educational livestreams on YouTube and Twitch, where he taught and commented on both traditional and blitz chess. A top-ranked player in both formats, he won the U.S. National Blitz Championship in August 2025. Naroditsky coached junior players at the Charlotte Chess Center in North Carolina after studying history at Stanford University. His death has deeply affected the global chess community, with fellow grandmasters like Hikaru Nakamura and Benjamin Bok expressing grief and admiration for his contributions to making chess accessible and enjoyable for fans worldwide.
title: American chess grandmaster Daniel Naroditsky dies at 29
